name: Ginseng
summary: Ginseng is a traditional herbal remedy derived from the roots of Panax species, used to support energy, cognitive function, mood, and resilience to stress.
description: Ginseng, particularly Panax ginseng (Asian ginseng) and Panax quinquefolius (American ginseng), is one of the most studied adaptogenic herbs in traditional and modern medicine. It contains active compounds called ginsenosides, which are thought to influence neurotransmission, reduce oxidative stress, and modulate the hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal (HPA) axis. Ginseng has been promoted for improving mental performance, reducing fatigue, supporting immune health, and alleviating symptoms of stress and depression. While some clinical trials support these effects, results are mixed, and efficacy varies depending on the species, extract standardization, and duration of treatment.

metadata.natural_source: Panax ginseng (Asian ginseng), Panax quinquefolius (American ginseng)
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for medical indications)

contraindications: History of hormone-sensitive cancers (e.g., breast cancer)

items: May improve cognitive performance and attention
Acts as an adaptogen to help manage stress

sections.text: Ginsenosides, the active compounds in ginseng, modulate neurotransmitters such as dopamine, serotonin, and norepinephrine, reduce oxidative stress, and influence the HPA axis. They may improve mitochondrial function and cerebral blood flow, contributing to energy, cognition, and stress resilience.

adult.note: Dosing varies widely depending on extract type and species.

sections.pediatric: Not routinely recommended due to limited evidence.

sections.text: Effects on fatigue and cognition may appear within days to weeks; stress resilience and immune benefits may require several weeks of consistent use.

serious: Mania or overstimulation in rare cases

other: May cause overstimulation or insomnia if taken late in the day.
Not recommended for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.
Potential hormonal effects—use caution in hormone-sensitive conditions.

sections.lactation: Avoid due to limited safety information
sections.geriatrics: May be used with caution; monitor cardiovascular status

sections.text: No tapering required; can be discontinued without withdrawal.

items: Panax ginseng (Asian/Korean) is generally more stimulating, while American ginseng may have more calming effects.
Some evidence suggests benefits for fatigue and quality of life in cancer patients.
Effects are highly dependent on extract quality and ginsenoside concentration.
